c74object.name: entrymatcher
c74object.digest: Flexible matching / storage / querying of multidimensional data
c74object.description: entrymatcher is an object for finding the most closely matching items in a scalable N-dimensional space, using variable matching criteria. The original reason for creating the entrymatcher object was to provide a way of matching audio samples using audio features (or descriptors) that had been calculated using the descriptors~ object. Data is added to the object in "entries", which are rows of values (ints, floats or symbols) that fill a predetermined number of columns. Columns are named to allow them to be specified by descriptive name, rather than only by index number, making it possible to alter the order and size of data sets easily. Each entry is also specified with an identifier (of any basic max data type), so that it can also be referred to regardless of position in the data set. Various tests may be performed on each column of data, either individually or in combination, as appropriate to the data (exact match, within given distance, greater than, less than etc.) to determine matching entries. Values from specified columns may be queried at will (in the case where each entry represents a sample this is useful in retrieving data once a particular sample has been matched). Matched entries are returned as a set of lists, with the best (closest) matches first. In practice a large number of matching scenarios and data lookup requirements can be satisfied.

objarg.name: Max_entries
objarg.description: The first argument takes an int to set the maximum number of entries that entrymatcher will recognise. The default max entries is 1

objarg.name: Number_of_columns
objarg.description: The second argument takes an int to set the number of columns allowed per entry.

method.name: bang
method.description: A bang causes an output of all the data that satisfies the matchers message (maximum 1024).

method.name: clear
method.description: The clear message clears all the currently stored entries and matchers. The reset message does the same.

method.name: dump
method.description: The dump message will output all the stored data out the fourth outlet.

method.name: dictionary
method.description: TEXT HERE

method.name: entry
method.digest: Set the columns for each entry
method.description:
The entry message is used to send data into entrymatcher that can be queried using the index, lookup and match messages.
The entry message should first contain a unique identifier (of any data type) that can be used by the index and lookup messages to query it. The message should then contain a list with length equal to the columns argument in the entrymatcher object. The list should contain data corresponding to the data types specified by the labelmodes message.
Ex.
with labelmode set as:
labelmode / 0 0 1
An entry should look like:
entry / identifier / numeric numeric symbolic
If a new entry is set with an identifier already in use, the old entry will be replaced.

method.name: index
method.digest: query an entry and output out the fourth outlet
method.description:
Sending the index message followed by an int will output the corresponding entry in its entirety as a list out the fourth outlet. The index message is dependent on the order that the entries are input (index 2 is the second entry that was input).
The index message can also include a list of names (set by the names message) or ints (corresponding to the column index) to return only specific columns in any order.
Also adding the symbol `identifier` to the message will output the identifier of the entry. This can again be in any order.
The message should be formatted as:
index / int (index of entry to query) / OPTIONAL list of names or ints (in any order) / OPTIONAL identifier (can be at any point in the list of names)

method.name: labelmodes
method.digest: Set the labelmodes for each column
method.description:
The labelmodes message followed by a list of ints sets the labelmodes for each column. The list should have a length equal to the columns argument in the entrymatcher object.
The list should contain ints of either 0 or 1, where a 0 represents a numeric label, and a 1 represents a symbolic label for each column.
The message should be formatted as:
labelmodes / list of modes

method.name: lookup
method.digest: query an entry and output out the fourth outlet
method.description:
Sending the lookup message followed by the identifier of a specific entry, will output the entry in its entirety as a list out the fourth outlet.
The lookup message can also include a list of names (set by the names message) or ints (corresponding to the column index) to return only specific columns in any order.
The message should be formatted as:
lookup / identifier (name of entry to query) / OPTIONAL list of names or ints (in any order)

method.name: looporder
method.description: TEXT HERE

method.name: match
method.description:
Sending the match message with no arguments works the same as sending a bang.
Adding an int (n) to the message will tell entrymatcher to only output the closest n matches.
Adding a float to the message will set a ratio of matches for entrymatcher to output.
For example: match / 0.5 will only return the top 50% of matches.
Both an int and a float can be specified in any order to provide to conditions for match.
For example: match / 0.5 / 2 will only return the top 50% of matches and no more than 2.
A third value can be set to specify the largest allowable distance value to match.
For example: match / 1024 / 1. / 0.3 will return up to 1024 matches, the top 100% (all of them), keeping all matches with a distance value of 0.3 or less.

method.name: matchers
method.description:
The matchers message is used to set a number of tests that entries must satisfy when the match message is sent in order to be output. For each test you may specify multiple target values. If one of these matches then the entry will match.
Some of the tests have a calculation that is used to find the distance. This distance value is then used to determine which values are closest when the match message is sent with arguments that filter the distance.
The message should be formatted as:
matchers / column identifier or number / test symbol or name / scaling value (if required) / target values / (repeat for multiple tests)
To see how matchers work and a list of all the symbols it accepts, see the third tab of the entrymatcher help file.

method.name: names
method.digest: Set the name for each column
method.description:
The names message followed by a list of symbols sets the names for each column. The list should have a length equal to the columns argument in the entrymatcher object.
The list should contain symbols which can be used by the index and lookup messages to query specific columns.
The message should be formatted as:
names / list of names

method.name: open
method.description: The open message will open a table displaying all the contents of entrymatcher. The colums are labelled as the index(#), identifier, and then the names set with the names message.

method.name: read
method.description: The read message will prompt you to open a new file, such as one written previously using the write message. The data in the new file will then replace the contents of entrymatcher.

method.name: refer
method.description: TEXT HERE

method.name: remove
method.description: The remove message followed by a symbol corresponding to an identifier will remove that item from entrymatcher.

method.name: removeif
method.description: TEXT HERE

method.name: reset
method.description: Same as clear.

method.name: resize
method.description: TEXT HERE

method.name: stats
method.description: TEXT HERE

method.name: write
method.description: The write message will create a new file containing a dict of the contents inside entrymatcher

attribute.name: embed
attribute.digest: Save the data with the patch
attribute.description: An int (0/off or 1/on) can be used to embed the data within the patch when the patch is saved.

entry.name: list
entry.description:
entrymatcher has four outlets.
The first outlet outputs a list of the indicies of entries that satisfied the matchers message when the match message is received.
The second outlet outputs a list of the identifiers of entries that satisfied the matchers message when the match message is received.
The third outlet outputs a list of the distances of entries (calculated according to the matchers message)that satisfied the matchers message when the match message is received.
The fourth outlet outputs a list of the entry columns that are satisfied when the lookup or index message is received. It also outputs all the data when the dump message is received.
